questions.stem: A 58-year-old patient presents after a left hemisphere stroke with fluent but meaningless speech, frequent neologisms, and severely impaired comprehension. The patient appears unaware of his deficits. Which of the following best describes the location of the lesion?

options.text: Left posterior superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann area 22)
Arcuate fasciculus connecting frontal and temporal regions

questions.explanation: This presentation is classic Wernicke's aphasia (receptive/fluent aphasia): fluent but meaningless speech, impaired comprehension, and anosognosia for the deficit. Wernicke's area is located in the left posterior superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann area 22). Broca's area damage (option A) produces nonfluent, effortful speech with preserved comprehension. Arcuate fasciculus damage (option C) produces conduction aphasia with intact fluency and comprehension but impaired repetition. Right parietal damage (option D) typically produces hemispatial neglect, not aphasia.

questions.stem: In Roger Sperry's split-brain experiments, when an image of an object was presented exclusively to the left visual field of a patient who had undergone corpus callosotomy, the patient could NOT:

options.text: Select the object with the left hand from a group of hidden objects
Recognize the object when it was presented again to the same visual field
Process the visuospatial features of the object

questions.explanation: In split-brain patients, information presented to the left visual field is projected to the right hemisphere. Because the corpus callosum is severed, the information cannot reach the left hemisphere's language centers. Therefore, the patient cannot verbally name the object but can select it with the left hand (controlled by the right hemisphere), can recognize it again, and can process its visuospatial features (a right hemisphere strength).

questions.stem: A patient with bilateral amygdala damage would most likely demonstrate which of the following deficits?

options.text: Severe anterograde amnesia for declarative information
Impaired ability to recognize fear in facial expressions
Loss of the ability to regulate body temperature

questions.explanation: The amygdala is critical for emotional processing, particularly fear conditioning and threat detection. Bilateral amygdala damage impairs the ability to recognize negative emotions in facial expressions, especially fear. This is distinct from anterograde amnesia (hippocampal damage), motor initiation deficits (basal ganglia damage), and thermoregulation problems (hypothalamic damage). Bilateral amygdala damage is also associated with Kluver-Bucy syndrome features.

questions.stem: Which of the following is the only sensory modality that does NOT relay through the thalamus before reaching the cerebral cortex?
questions.explanation: Olfaction (smell) is the only sensory modality that bypasses the thalamus. Olfactory information travels directly from the olfactory bulb to the piriform cortex and amygdala. All other sensory modalities -- vision (via the lateral geniculate nucleus), audition (via the medial geniculate nucleus), and somatosensation (via the ventral posterolateral nucleus) -- relay through specific thalamic nuclei before reaching their respective cortical areas.

questions.stem: A neuropsychological evaluation reveals that a patient can understand spoken language and produce fluent spontaneous speech, but is severely impaired when asked to repeat words or phrases. This presentation is most consistent with damage to the:

options.text: Angular gyrus of the dominant hemisphere

questions.explanation: This is conduction aphasia: fluent speech, intact comprehension, but severely impaired repetition. It results from damage to the arcuate fasciculus, the white matter tract connecting Wernicke's area (comprehension) to Broca's area (production). Without this connection, repetition is impaired because linguistic information cannot be transferred from comprehension centers to production centers, even though each area functions independently. Angular gyrus damage produces Gerstmann's syndrome (finger agnosia, acalculia, agraphia, left-right confusion).

questions.stem: Select all structures that are components of the basal ganglia involved in the regulation of voluntary movement.
questions.explanation: The basal ganglia include the caudate nucleus, putamen, globus pallidus, subthalamic nucleus, and substantia nigra. The caudate and putamen together form the striatum and are involved in motor planning and procedural learning. The globus pallidus is the primary output nucleus sending inhibitory signals to the thalamus. The hippocampus is a limbic structure involved in declarative memory, and the mammillary bodies are part of the Papez circuit involved in memory relay.

questions.stem: Select all functions that are primarily associated with the RIGHT cerebral hemisphere in most right-handed individuals.

options.text: Holistic and gestalt processing of information

questions.explanation: The right hemisphere specializes in visuospatial processing, face recognition, emotional prosody, musical perception, and holistic/gestalt processing. Language production and comprehension are primarily left-hemisphere functions (in approximately 95% of right-handers), as is sequential and analytical processing. The right hemisphere processes information in a more global, gestalt manner, while the left hemisphere processes in a more analytical, sequential manner.

questions.stem: Select all symptoms that would be expected following damage to the right parietal lobe.

options.text: Hemispatial neglect of the left side of space
Anosognosia (unawareness of one's own neurological deficit)
Contralateral sensory loss on the left side of the body

questions.explanation: Right parietal damage commonly produces hemispatial neglect of the left side of space (the right parietal lobe attends to both sides of space), anosognosia (unawareness of deficit), and contralateral sensory loss from damage to the somatosensory cortex. Broca's aphasia results from left inferior frontal damage, and Wernicke's aphasia results from left posterior superior temporal damage. Hemispatial neglect is more common and severe after right-hemisphere damage because the left hemisphere cannot compensate for attention to the left side of space.

questions.stem: Select all statements that accurately describe functions of the hypothalamus.

options.text: The lateral hypothalamus serves as a hunger center; its destruction causes aphagia
The suprachiasmatic nucleus serves as the master biological clock controlling circadian rhythms
It serves as the primary sensory relay station for all senses except olfaction
It regulates the pituitary gland through releasing and inhibiting hormones
It contains place cells that form cognitive maps for spatial navigation

questions.explanation: The hypothalamus contains the lateral hypothalamus (hunger center, lesion causes aphagia), the suprachiasmatic nucleus (master circadian clock), and regulates the pituitary gland through the HPA axis. The thalamus (not hypothalamus) is the primary sensory relay station. Place cells are located in the hippocampus, not the hypothalamus. The ventromedial hypothalamus serves as the satiety center (lesion causes hyperphagia).

questions.stem: Select all conditions that are associated with dysfunction of the basal ganglia.
questions.explanation: Parkinson's disease involves degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra (part of basal ganglia circuitry). Huntington's disease involves degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen. Research has found increased basal ganglia activity in OCD. Korsakoff's syndrome is associated with damage to the thalamus (dorsomedial nucleus) and mammillary bodies. Conduction aphasia results from arcuate fasciculus damage, not basal ganglia dysfunction.

questions.stem: Match each clinical syndrome with the brain structure whose damage most commonly produces it.
questions.explanation: Kluver-Bucy syndrome results from bilateral amygdala damage (and surrounding temporal structures), producing psychic blindness, reduced fear, hypersexuality, and hyperorality. Anterograde amnesia for declarative information is the hallmark of bilateral hippocampal damage (as in patient H.M.). Hemiballismus (violent flinging movements of contralateral limbs) results from subthalamic nucleus lesions. Ataxia and intention tremor are the hallmarks of cerebellar damage.

questions.stem: Match each thalamic nucleus with the sensory information it relays.

columns.text: Visual information to primary visual cortex
Memory and emotion via prefrontal cortex connections
Auditory information to primary auditory cortex

questions.explanation: The LGN relays visual information from the optic tract to V1. The MGN relays auditory information from the inferior colliculus to primary auditory cortex. The VPL relays somatosensory information from the body to the primary somatosensory cortex. The dorsomedial nucleus connects to the prefrontal cortex and is involved in memory and emotion; its damage is implicated in Korsakoff's syndrome.

questions.stem: For each cortical lobe, select ALL associated functions. Each row has exactly one correct answer.
questions.explanation: The frontal lobe houses the prefrontal cortex responsible for executive functions including planning, working memory, and cognitive flexibility. The parietal lobe contains the primary somatosensory cortex (postcentral gyrus) which processes touch, pressure, temperature, and proprioception. The temporal lobe contains Wernicke's area responsible for language comprehension. The occipital lobe contains the primary visual cortex (V1) and visual association areas for visual processing.

questions.stem: For each brainstem structure, select ALL neurotransmitter systems or functions it is primarily associated with.
questions.explanation: The locus coeruleus in the pons is the brain's primary source of norepinephrine, involved in arousal, attention, and the stress response. The raphe nuclei in the medulla are the primary source of serotonin, regulating mood and sleep. The ventral tegmental area produces dopamine for the mesolimbic reward pathway (projecting to the nucleus accumbens and prefrontal cortex). The substantia nigra produces dopamine for the nigrostriatal pathway involved in motor control; its degeneration causes Parkinson's disease.

questions.stem: Damage to the {{blank1}} produces nonfluent, effortful speech with preserved comprehension, while damage to the {{blank2}} produces fluent but meaningless speech with impaired comprehension. Damage to the {{blank3}}, which connects these two regions, produces conduction aphasia characterized by impaired {{blank4}} despite intact fluency and comprehension.

options.text: left posterior superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area)
left posterior superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area)

questions.explanation: Broca's area (left inferior frontal gyrus, Brodmann areas 44-45) damage produces expressive/nonfluent aphasia with preserved comprehension. Wernicke's area (left posterior superior temporal gyrus, Brodmann area 22) damage produces receptive/fluent aphasia with impaired comprehension. The arcuate fasciculus connects these two areas; its damage produces conduction aphasia characterized by intact fluency and comprehension but severely impaired repetition.

questions.stem: The hypothalamus regulates feeding behavior through two key centers: the {{blank1}} is the hunger center (lesions cause aphagia), while the {{blank2}} is the satiety center (lesions cause hyperphagia). The hypothalamus also contains the {{blank3}}, which serves as the master biological clock regulating circadian rhythms, and controls the endocrine system through its connection with the {{blank4}}.
questions.explanation: The lateral hypothalamus is the hunger center ('lateral leanness' mnemonic -- lesions cause aphagia and weight loss). The ventromedial hypothalamus is the satiety center ('ventromedial voluminosity' -- lesions cause hyperphagia and obesity). The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) is the master biological clock entrained by light from the retina. The hypothalamus controls the endocrine system through its connection with the pituitary gland ('master gland'), regulating the HPA axis.

questions.stem: A 65-year-old man presents with progressively worsening bradykinesia, resting tremor in his right hand, cogwheel rigidity, and postural instability over the past 18 months. His cognitive function is relatively preserved. Identify the contributing factors, central diagnosis, and clinical implications.

options.text: Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra
Disruption of the nigrostriatal dopamine pathway to the striatum
Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen
Lesion of the subthalamic nucleus disrupting basal ganglia output
Symptoms are hypokinetic, reflecting difficulty initiating and executing movement
Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus may reduce symptoms
The presentation is hyperkinetic with involuntary chorea movements
The patient will show rapid cognitive decline as the primary feature

questions.explanation: Parkinson's disease is caused by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, disrupting the nigrostriatal pathway to the striatum. This produces hypokinetic symptoms (bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, postural instability) because reduced dopamine in the direct pathway makes it harder to initiate movement. Deep brain stimulation of the subthalamic nucleus can reduce symptoms. Huntington's disease (degeneration of caudate/putamen GABAergic neurons) produces hyperkinetic chorea. Subthalamic nucleus lesions cause hemiballismus.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman is referred for neuropsychological evaluation after a right parietal stroke. Her husband reports she only eats food from the right side of her plate, applies makeup only to the right side of her face, and denies having any problems. Identify the contributing factors, central concept, and expected assessment findings.

options.text: The right parietal lobe normally attends to both sides of space
The left hemisphere cannot compensate for attention to the left side of space
Bilateral hippocampal damage has impaired spatial memory formation
Damage to the arcuate fasciculus has disconnected language areas
Cortical blindness in the left visual field
Line bisection tasks will show rightward deviation from true midpoint
When asked to copy a drawing, she will omit the left side of the figure
She will show impaired repetition of spoken words and phrases
Standard visual acuity testing will reveal bilateral blindness

questions.explanation: This patient has left hemispatial neglect with anosognosia from right parietal damage. The right parietal lobe normally attends to both sides of space, while the left parietal lobe primarily attends to the right. After right parietal damage, the left hemisphere cannot compensate for the left side. On assessment, line bisection shows rightward deviation and figure copying omits left-sided details. This is not cortical blindness (visual acuity is intact) or a language deficit. The patient's denial of problems reflects anosognosia, commonly associated with right parietal damage.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that are accurate regarding the hippocampus and its clinical significance.
questions.passage: The hippocampus is a medial temporal lobe structure essential for memory. [The hippocampus is critical for the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories from short-term to long-term storage]. [Bilateral hippocampal damage primarily impairs procedural memory while leaving declarative memory intact]. [The hippocampus contains place cells that fire when an animal occupies a specific location, forming cognitive maps for spatial navigation]. [Chronic stress-induced cortisol elevations are neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons and impair declarative memory]. [The hippocampus is the brain's primary source of serotonin, regulating mood and sleep]. [Neuroimaging studies have linked PTSD to reduced hippocampal volume].

highlightableSegments.text: The hippocampus is critical for the consolidation of new declarative (explicit) memories from short-term to long-term storage
Bilateral hippocampal damage primarily impairs procedural memory while leaving declarative memory intact
The hippocampus contains place cells that fire when an animal occupies a specific location, forming cognitive maps for spatial navigation
Chronic stress-induced cortisol elevations are neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons and impair declarative memory
The hippocampus is the brain's primary source of serotonin, regulating mood and sleep
Neuroimaging studies have linked PTSD to reduced hippocampal volume

questions.explanation: The hippocampus consolidates declarative (not procedural) memories. Bilateral hippocampal damage causes severe anterograde amnesia for declarative information (as in patient H.M.), while procedural memory remains relatively intact. The hippocampus does contain place cells (O'Keefe, Nobel Prize 2014). Cortisol is neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons. PTSD is associated with reduced hippocampal volume. The raphe nuclei (not hippocampus) are the brain's primary source of serotonin.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the cerebellum and its clinical significance.
questions.passage: The cerebellum is a critical brain structure for motor function and beyond. [The cerebellum contains approximately 50% of the brain's neurons despite comprising only 10% of brain volume]. [Damage to the cerebellum produces paralysis on the contralateral side of the body]. [Cerebellar damage causes ataxia, dysarthria, and intention tremor that worsens as the hand approaches a target]. [The cerebellum is essential for classical conditioning of motor responses such as eyeblink conditioning]. [The cerebellum's primary role is in language comprehension and speech production]. [Cerebellar intention tremor is clinically distinct from the resting tremor of Parkinson's disease].

highlightableSegments.text: The cerebellum contains approximately 50% of the brain's neurons despite comprising only 10% of brain volume
Damage to the cerebellum produces paralysis on the contralateral side of the body
Cerebellar damage causes ataxia, dysarthria, and intention tremor that worsens as the hand approaches a target
The cerebellum is essential for classical conditioning of motor responses such as eyeblink conditioning
The cerebellum's primary role is in language comprehension and speech production
Cerebellar intention tremor is clinically distinct from the resting tremor of Parkinson's disease

questions.explanation: The cerebellum does contain approximately 50% of the brain's neurons. Critically, cerebellar damage does NOT cause paralysis -- it causes ataxia (loss of coordination), dysarthria, and intention tremor. Intention tremor worsens as the hand approaches a target, unlike Parkinson's resting tremor which occurs at rest. The cerebellum is essential for eyeblink conditioning and motor learning. While the cerebellum has some recognized role in language and cognition, its PRIMARY role is motor coordination, not language comprehension (which is a function of Wernicke's area).

questions.stem: Arrange the following structures from MOST SUPERIOR (top of the brainstem) to MOST INFERIOR (closest to the spinal cord) within the brainstem hierarchy.

items.text: Midbrain (mesencephalon) -- contains superior/inferior colliculi and substantia nigra
Pons -- contains locus coeruleus and cranial nerve nuclei V-VIII
Medulla oblongata -- contains raphe nuclei and vital autonomic centers
Pyramidal decussation -- where motor fibers cross to the contralateral side
Spinal cord junction -- where brainstem transitions to spinal cord
Cervical spinal cord -- beginning of the spinal cord proper

questions.explanation: The brainstem is arranged from superior to inferior as: midbrain (mesencephalon), pons, and medulla oblongata. The midbrain sits at the top, connecting to the diencephalon. The pons sits below the midbrain and relays information between the cerebellum and cortex. The medulla is the most inferior brainstem structure and contains the pyramidal decussation near its junction with the spinal cord, where motor fibers cross to explain contralateral motor control. Below this is the spinal cord proper, beginning with the cervical segments.

questions.stem: Arrange the following steps of LeDoux's 'low road' fear response pathway in the correct order, from initial stimulus detection to behavioral response.

items.text: A threatening sensory stimulus (e.g., a snake-like shape) is detected by sensory receptors
Sensory information is rapidly transmitted to the thalamus
The thalamus sends a coarse, rapid signal directly to the amygdala (low road)
The amygdala activates the hypothalamus and brainstem autonomic centers
Stress hormones are released and heart rate, blood pressure, and respiration increase
A freezing or flight response is initiated before conscious cortical processing is complete

questions.explanation: LeDoux's 'low road' describes the rapid, subcortical fear response pathway. A threatening stimulus activates sensory receptors, which transmit information to the thalamus. The thalamus sends a rapid, coarse signal directly to the amygdala (bypassing the cortex), which then activates the hypothalamus and brainstem to trigger autonomic responses (increased heart rate, blood pressure, stress hormones). The behavioral fear response (freezing/flight) occurs before the slower cortical 'high road' completes its more detailed analysis. This system enables survival-critical speed at the cost of accuracy.

questions.stem: A researcher tracks motor symptoms and cognitive symptoms in a patient with Huntington's disease over five years following diagnosis. The data below represents symptom severity scores (0-100) at annual intervals.
questions.question: Based on this data, which statement best describes the progression of Huntington's disease?

options.text: Chorea improves over time while cognitive function remains stable
As chorea severity increases, cognitive function shows a corresponding progressive decline, reflecting the progressive degeneration of the caudate and putamen
Cognitive decline precedes motor symptoms by several years, with chorea appearing only in late stages
Both chorea and cognitive function scores improve with standard pharmacological treatment

questions.explanation: Huntington's disease involves progressive degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate nucleus and putamen (components of the basal ganglia/striatum). This degeneration produces both hyperkinetic motor symptoms (chorea -- involuntary writhing movements that progressively worsen) and cognitive decline. The data shows chorea severity steadily increasing (15 to 80) while cognitive function steadily declines (85 to 22), reflecting the progressive nature of the neurodegeneration. Both motor and cognitive symptoms worsen in parallel because the caudate nucleus is involved in both motor control and cognitive functions.

questions.stem: A clinical researcher examines the relationship between hippocampal volume and cortisol levels in patients with PTSD compared to healthy controls over a 4-year longitudinal study. The data shows mean hippocampal volume values for each group.
questions.question: Which interpretation of the data is most consistent with current neurobiological understanding of PTSD?

options.text: The PTSD group shows progressive hippocampal volume reduction consistent with the neurotoxic effects of chronic cortisol elevation on hippocampal neurons
Both groups show equivalent hippocampal atrophy, suggesting no specific effect of PTSD on brain structure
The control group shows more hippocampal atrophy than the PTSD group
Hippocampal volume in the PTSD group increases over time due to stress-induced neurogenesis

questions.explanation: The data shows progressive hippocampal volume reduction in the PTSD group (3200 to 2650 mm3, a 17% decline) compared to minimal change in controls (3500 to 3420 mm3, a 2% decline). This is consistent with the well-established finding that chronic stress-induced cortisol elevations are neurotoxic to hippocampal neurons. The hippocampus is particularly vulnerable to stress-related damage because it has a high density of glucocorticoid receptors. PTSD is associated with sustained HPA axis dysregulation, leading to elevated cortisol levels that progressively damage hippocampal tissue.

questions.stem: Categorize each symptom or clinical finding with the brain structure whose damage most commonly produces it.

items.text: Broca's aphasia (nonfluent speech with preserved comprehension)
Hemispatial neglect of contralateral space
Wernicke's aphasia (fluent meaningless speech with impaired comprehension)
Personality changes, disinhibition, and impaired executive function
Gerstmann's syndrome (finger agnosia, agraphia, acalculia)
Prosopagnosia (inability to recognize familiar faces)

questions.explanation: Frontal lobe damage produces Broca's aphasia (left inferior frontal gyrus) and personality changes, disinhibition, and impaired executive function (prefrontal cortex, as demonstrated by Phineas Gage). Parietal lobe damage produces hemispatial neglect (especially right parietal) and Gerstmann's syndrome (left angular gyrus damage causing finger agnosia, agraphia, acalculia, and left-right confusion). Temporal lobe damage produces Wernicke's aphasia (left posterior superior temporal gyrus) and prosopagnosia (fusiform face area in the inferotemporal cortex).

questions.stem: Categorize each clinical feature as characteristic of either Parkinson's disease, Huntington's disease, or cerebellar damage.

items.text: Resting tremor that diminishes with intentional movement
Chorea (involuntary writhing, dance-like movements)
Ataxia and gait instability without paralysis
Bradykinesia and cogwheel rigidity from dopamine depletion
Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen
Intention tremor that worsens as hand approaches target

questions.explanation: Parkinson's disease (substantia nigra dopamine loss) produces hypokinetic symptoms: resting tremor (diminishes with movement), bradykinesia, and cogwheel rigidity. Huntington's disease (degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate and putamen) produces hyperkinetic symptoms, primarily chorea. Cerebellar damage produces ataxia (loss of coordination without paralysis) and intention tremor (which worsens as the hand approaches a target, the opposite pattern from Parkinson's resting tremor). This distinction between resting tremor and intention tremor is a high-yield EPPP topic.
